title: A man sold each of the two horses for ₹ 990 giving him a 20% profit on one horse and a loss of 20% on the other. What is his total profit or loss percentage? - Quora

response.answer_text: Statement of the given problem,A man sold each of the two horses for ₹ 990 giving him a 20% profit on one horse and a loss of 20% on the other. What is his total profit or loss percentage?Let C1 & C2 denote cost-prices of two horses respectively.From above data we get following relations,(1 + 20/100)*C1 = 990 or C1 = 990/1.20 = 825 (₹) …… (1a)(1 - 20/100)*C2 = 990 or C2 = 990/0.80 = 1237.5 (₹) …… (1b)Hence from (1a) & (1b) we get,Total cost-price = 825 + 1237.5 = 2062.5 (₹)Total sell-price = 990 + 990 = 1980 (₹)Therefore overall loss percentage = 100*(2062.5 - 1980)/2062.5 = 4% [Ans]

₹990= 1.2 xC1, and also 0.80 x C2 ; where C1 and C2 are the costs of profit making and the loss making horses respectively. So C1=990/1.2 = 825 ₹ . Similarly C2= 990/0.8= 1237.5 ₹ So his total cost is 1237.5+825 = 2062.5 ₹ and he gets 990x2 = 1980 ₹ So he loses 2062.5 - 1980 = 82.5 ₹ . Now the %age loss is 82.5 x100/2062.5 =4% //
